comment_data.body: The `names` param already can be a function that does this?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3023,6 +3023,11 @@ vim.fs.find({names}, {opts})                                   *vim.fs.find()*
                  • {limit}? (`number`, default: `1`) Stop the search after
                    finding this many matches. Use `math.huge` to place no
                    limit on the number of matches.
+                 • {skip}? (`(fun(dir_name: string): boolean)?`) Do not
+                   traverse matching directories. If omitted, all directories

comment_data.body: This could be worth adding, since checking for a symlink may be more than a simple matter of a single `fs_stat` ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3023,6 +3023,11 @@ vim.fs.find({names}, {opts})                                   *vim.fs.find()*
                  • {limit}? (`number`, default: `1`) Stop the search after
                    finding this many matches. Use `math.huge` to place no
                    limit on the number of matches.
+                 • {skip}? (`(fun(dir_name: string): boolean)?`) Do not
+                   traverse matching directories. If omitted, all directories
+                   are searched recursively.
+                 • {follow}? (`boolean`, default: `true`) Follow symbolic

comment_data.body: this is a perf cost, which should only be paid if it's actually necessary (i.e. depending on the `follow` param)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -308,6 +318,8 @@ function M.find(names, opts)
 
       for other, type_ in M.dir(dir) do
         local f = M.joinpath(dir, other)
+        local stat = vim.uv.fs_stat(f)

comment_data.body: not as it is now since name param just controls what gets found not whether or not to recursively search.

comment_data.body: it does probably need extra checks in windows, since I see the test failed there
comment_data.diff_hunk:

                  • {limit}? (`number`, default: `1`) Stop the search after

@@ -190,6 +190,14 @@ end
 --- Use `math.huge` to place no limit on the number of matches.
 --- (default: `1`)
 --- @field limit? number
+---
+--- Do not traverse matching directories.
+--- If omitted, all directories are searched recursively.
+--- @field skip? (fun(dir_name: string): boolean)|nil

comment_data.body: please search for "predicate", "filter", "skip", and any other related concept, in the :help docs to see which is the most common. I'm wondering if positive logic ("match") or negative logic ("skip") is more common and more intuitive.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3039,6 +3039,11 @@ vim.fs.find({names}, {opts})                                   *vim.fs.find()*
                  • {limit}? (`number`, default: `1`) Stop the search after
                    finding this many matches. Use `math.huge` to place no
                    limit on the number of matches.
+                 • {skip}? (`fun(dir: string): boolean`) Do not traverse

comment_regular_data.body: I think the issue with windows might be cause because VM might not have the permissions create the link in the first place, but at the moment I don't have a windows system to confirm this.

Apparently the problem was indeed permissions related, not on creation but on read, `vim.uv.fs_stat(f)` was getting `EPERM` when the symlink was created without `junction=true` on windows, causing the test to fail.
